_exec_summary.SummaryText:
4768 LDEQ Facility ID Number

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
The Lowry Plant is committed to protecting the health and safety of company personnel, contractors working in the facility, our neighbors in the surrounding community and the environment.  This commitment is strongly supported by senior management and is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as employee training and in considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our facility. The facility does not anticipate having any type of uncontrolled release.  However if an uncontrolled release does occur, the personnel at the facility will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the plant, and notify the necessary outside agencies.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Lowry Plant is a facility which receives raw natural gas from well production.  The raw gas is dehydrated and contaminants removed.  Marketable natural gas, composed mainly of methane, is delivered via pipelines.  Natural gas liquids are extracted and delivered to market via pipeline and transport vehicles.  The extracted natural gas liquid is a flammable mixture composed mainly of ethane, propane, butane, i-butane, pentane and i-pentane.  Condensate is also produced, which can contain methane, ethane, propane, butane, i-butane, pentane, i-pentane and hexanes. There are no listed toxic substances which exceed their respective threshold quantities stored at this facility.

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Several storage vessels within the facility process were evaluated for the worst case and alternative release scenarios.  Results of the worst case release scenario indicate that the process is subject to RMP Program Level 1 requirements.  Details of the worst case release scenario are included with the backup documentation associated with this RMP plan.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
This

facility is regulated by 29CFR 1910.119 (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals),   1910.38 (Employee Emergency Plans), as well as other federal, state and local regulations which are in place to reduce the potential for the release of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.

This facility has implemented the PSM elements to facilitate accidental release prevention.  Process safety information, consisting of technical standards, specifications and levels, promotes safe process design and operation.  Process hazard analysis evaluates hazards against safeguards needed to mitigate likelihood of an accidental release. Process changes are managed through the management of change procedure, by considering the impact that a change will have on the rest of the process.  For new or significantly changed processes, a pre-startup safety review is conducted as a final check to enable safe start up.  

The employee participation program promotes the development of necessary expertise, experiences, judgment, and proactive initiative within the workforce.  A comprehensive training program ensures that employees are knowledgeable about the processes they are responsible to operate and control.  Operating procedures explain correct startup, operation and shutdown procedures for various equipment in the process.  The hot work program is in place to promote safety of jobs involving potential ignition sources.  The mechanical integrity program ensures that equipment is maintained inspected and tested for ongoing safety.  A contractor safety evaluation program is in place to ensure hire of contractors that will not compromise job or facility safety.   

The facility has a policy of investigating every incident, which may have possibly resulted in a release, in order to prevent a similar accident from recurring.  The facility has established an audit procedure to assure the continued integrity of the prevention program.

5 YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The Lowry Plant has not had a

ny RMP-reportable accidents within the last five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
This facility is a non-responding facility and has coordinated with the local fire department for response to large accidental releases.  As a non-responding facility, the RMP emergency response program and emergency response plan requirements (40 CFR 68.95) are not applicable at this facility.  However, the facility does maintain an emergency response plan that serves as guidance for facility employees to notify first responders, secure critical operations before evacuation, evacuate the facility, and account for personnel, among other items.  Facility personnel are trained in procedures and use of equipment appropriate to their role in response to small accidental releases.

MANAGEMENT SYSTEM
The Area Manager has overall responsibility for development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program and this facility.  Specific responsibilities are summarized in the backup documentation associated with this RMP plan.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The plant personnel are continually developing new ways to improve the safety of the facility.  This is done through responsibility matrices and training which is a vital part of any safety program.  Training is conducted according to a systematic schedule.  All new and modified equipment is designed with appropriate safety controls and devices.
